reconnaissance.question: Reconnaissance: Who could be the target of a Cross Site Scripting (XSS) attack?
reconnaissance.optionA: A random user of a website
reconnaissance.optionB: A frequent user of a website
reconnaissance.explaination: Anyone using a website can be the target, although the attacker may target a specific individual
reconnaissance.stage: Reconnaissence: The attacker gathers information about the target system, identifying potential vulnerabilities or weak points in the security measures.

reconnaissance.question: Reconnaissance: What might be vulnerable to a Cross Site Scripting (XSS) attack?
reconnaissance.explaination: The most common vulnerabilities exploited are poor or no input validation or the input data not being encoded
reconnaissance.stage: Reconnaissence: The attacker gathers information about the target system, identifying potential vulnerabilities or weak points in the security measures.

weaponisation.question: Weaponization: Which of these are not how a malicious script may try to evade detection?
weaponisation.optionC: Filtering by web application or browser
weaponisation.explaination: Putting the script in a zip file will not help evade detection, as it will not change the actual code
weaponisation.stage: Weaponization: The attacker creates a malicious script that can exploit the identified vulnerabilities.

weaponisation.question: Weaponization: What is the most common programming language used for XSS attacks?
weaponisation.explaination: The vast majority of XXS attacks use scripts created in JavaScript, with HTML also being quite common
weaponisation.stage: Weaponization: The attacker creates a malicious script that can exploit the identified vulnerabilities.

delivery.question: Delivery: Which XSS attack involves a malicious script being installed on a website's server?
delivery.explaination: Reflected XSS attacks are reflected off the server, rather than stored. Document Object Model based attacks are carried by modifying the original client side script
delivery.stage: Delivery: The attacker delivers the malicious script to the target system. This could be through the web browser or a link in a phishing email

delivery.question: Delivery: Which XSS attack could involve the user clicking a malicious link?
delivery.explaination: Stored XSS attacks are stored on a server, rather than relying on a link being clicked. Document Object Model based attacks are carried by modifying the original client side script
delivery.stage: Delivery: The attacker delivers the malicious script to the target system. This could be through the web browser or a link in a phishing email

delivery.question: Delivery: Which XSS attack is also known as client-side XSS?
delivery.explaination: Both Reflected ans Stored XSS attacks use servers, while DOM based attacks modify the original client side script
delivery.stage: Delivery: The attacker delivers the malicious script to the target system. This could be through the web browser or a link in a phishing email

exploitation.question: Exploitation: What can an XSS attack do?
exploitation.optionB: Send requests to the web server
exploitation.optionC: Access the victim's cookies or local storage
exploitation.explaination: The attacker might be able to do one of these actions or multiple at the same time, based on what they want to achieve
exploitation.stage: Exploitation: The malicious script is executed on the target system, exploiting the vulnerability

exploitation.question: Exploitation: Who/What executes the malicious script?
exploitation.explaination: Neither the user nor the attacker tend to execute the code, it is usually the victim's web browser thaat runs the script
exploitation.stage: Exploitation: The malicious script is executed on the target system, exploiting the vulnerability

installation.question: Installation: Which of the following could an XSS script install?
installation.explaination: An XSS attack can install various malicious programs or malware, including the 3 listed
installation.stage: Installation: Once the attacker gains access, they establish a foothold within the system. The attacker may install other malicious code to ensure that they can continue to exploit the system even after the initial script has been executed.

installation.question: Installation: What might an XSS attack install?
installation.optionA: A script that runs everytime the victim visits the web application
installation.optionB: A web shell that allows the attacker to remotely execute commands
installation.optionD: An XSS attack can't install anything
installation.explaination: An XSS attack can install code that will repeatedly run, or a web shell the attacker can use remotely, amongst other options
installation.stage: Installation: Once the attacker gains access, they establish a foothold within the system. The attacker may install other malicious code to ensure that they can continue to exploit the system even after the initial script has been executed.

command.question: Command and Control (C2): How does the attacker communicate with the malicious code?
command.explaination: The attacker has a variety of options for communication with the code, with all 3 being possible
command.stage: Command and Control (C2): Attackers set up communication channels to control the compromised system. This allows them to issue commands, exfiltrate data, or manipulate the system further. The C2 phase enables ongoing control and interaction with the compromised environment.

command.question: Command and Control(C2): What can the attacker do after an attack is initiated?
command.explaination: Depending on the attackers goals, they could do all 3 of these things or one specifically
command.stage: Command and Control (C2): Attackers set up communication channels to control the compromised system. This allows them to issue commands, exfiltrate data, or manipulate the system further. The C2 phase enables ongoing control and interaction with the compromised environment.
